title: 105_hr2777
content: The "Campaign Finance Reform Act of 1997" limits the amount of non-federal money that national political parties can contribute. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to limit contributions to national political party committees to $10,000 per year. This includes payments of gifts, subscriptions, loans, advances, or deposits in support of political committee activities. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 limits contributions to national political party committees to $10,000 per year, including payments made in support of political committee activities. SEC. 3. TREATMENT OF CERTAIN COMMUNICATIONS AS INDEPENDENT EXPENDITURES. Section 301(17) of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to define 'independent expenditure' as an expenditure made by a person advocating for a candidate without cooperation or consultation with the candidate or their committee. It includes communications with the candidate's name, image, or likeness within 90 days of an election. The amendment requires disclosure of independent expenditures exceeding $10,000 for communications related to Federal elections. SEC. 4. Restrictions on solicitation and transfer of funds by candidates and parties to certain nonprofit organizations under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Sec. 323 of the Federal Election Campaign Act prohibits candidates and officeholders from soliciting contributions for tax-exempt organizations they control. The Federal Election Campaign Act prohibits political party committees and entities from soliciting funds or making donations to tax-exempt organizations under section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SEC. 5. REQUIRING MONTHLY REPORTS FOR CERTAIN CANDIDATE COMMITTEES. Section 304(a)(2)(A)(iii) of the Federal Election Campaign Act is amended to require additional monthly reports for committees reporting over $50,000 in contributions, excluding November and December, with a year-end report due by January 31 of the following year. Other committees must file additional quarterly reports. The Federal Election Campaign Act requires committees to file additional quarterly reports, with the report for the quarter ending December 31 due by January 31 of the following year. Committees must also make reports available on the internet in electronic format. The Federal Election Campaign Act requires committees to file quarterly reports electronically and post them on the Internet. The term 'Internet' is defined as the international computer network of both Federal and non-Federal data networks. SEC. 6 of the Act states that if any provision or application is deemed invalid, the rest of the Act will also be considered invalid. SEC. 7 specifies that the amendments apply to contributions or expenditures made after the enactment date of the Act.
